From Markdown to Blog Post: Converting Documentation into a Reproducible ZZCOLLAB Workflow

A complete guide to integrating technical reference materials into your Quarto blog system

Quarto
ZZCOLLAB
Blog Development
Documentation
Workflow
Learn how to convert standalone markdown documentation into a fully-featured, reproducible blog post using ZZCOLLAB and Quarto. Includes the complete workflow, decision-making process, and a detailed checklist.
Author

Ronald G. Thomas

Published

December 2, 2025

A structured workflow for publishing technical documentation with reproducibility built-in

1 Introduction

You have excellent technical documentation in markdown format. It explains complex processes clearly, includes working code examples, and provides valuable guidance. But it sits as a standalone file on your disk, never reaching the audience that could benefit from it.

This post documents how to transform that markdown documentation into a professional, publishable blog post integrated with your Quarto blog system—while maintaining reproducibility through ZZCOLLAB and Docker.

1.1 What You’ll Learn

  • The complete workflow: Step-by-step process for converting markdown to blog post
  • Key decisions: How to structure content for blog format
  • Technical integration: Symlinks, Quarto compatibility, and git workflow
  • Verification steps: Testing and validation before publication
  • Troubleshooting: Common issues and solutions
  • Timeline: Realistic expectations (40 minutes total)

1.2 Why This Matters

Blog posts discoverable through search and social sharing reach a broader audience than markdown files in your project directories. Using ZZCOLLAB ensures:

  • Reproducibility - Docker + renv lock exact environment
  • Discoverability - Integrated with your blog’s search and tagging
  • Professionalism - Proper metadata, structure, and styling
  • Maintainability - Version controlled and easily updated
  • Extensibility - Can add data analysis, visualizations, or interactive elements later

2 Part 1: Prerequisites and Planning

2.1 Tools You’ll Need

Must Have: - ZZCOLLAB framework (installed) - Quarto (for rendering) - Git (version control) - Bash shell

Nice to Have: - GitHub CLI (gh) for automation - Docker (for full reproducibility) - Local Quarto preview capability

2.2 Initial Assessment: 5 Minutes

Before starting, evaluate your source markdown:

Ask Yourself: 1. How long is it? (200 lines? 600 lines?) 2. Does it have code examples? (bash, R, Python?) 3. Does it need images? (hero image, embedded diagrams?) 4. Is it a tutorial, reference guide, or how-to? 5. What’s the target audience?

Example: GitHub Archive Post

- Length: ~600 lines (substantial)
- Code: Yes (bash script)
- Images: Yes (hero + concept)
- Type: How-to guide + reference
- Audience: DevOps engineers
- Estimate: 10 minutes to convert content

2.3 Make Key Decisions

Before initializing the project, decide:

Decision GitHub Archive Your Post
Blog slug github_archive [kebab-case-name]
ZZCOLLAB profile ubuntu_standard_publishing Same (has Quarto)
Include analysis? No Yes / No
Media assets 2 images How many?
Categories DevOps, Git, etc ?

3 Part 2: Create the ZZCOLLAB Blog Project

3.1 Step 1: Create Directory

cd ~/prj/qblog/posts
mkdir my_blog_post && cd my_blog_post

Replace my_blog_post with your kebab-case slug (e.g., github_archive, python_async, data_pipeline).

3.2 Step 2: Initialize ZZCOLLAB

zzcollab -r ubuntu_standard_publishing

This creates: - Standard project structure (analysis/, R/, tests/) - Dockerfile (reproducible environment) - renv.lock (R package versions) - Makefile (build automation) - .zzcollab/manifest.json (project metadata)

Expected output: ~20 lines of checkmarks showing successful initialization

3.3 Step 3: Set Up Blog Structure

./modules/setup_symlinks.sh

This creates the dual-symlink system that makes everything work:

At post root (for Quarto):

index.qmd → analysis/paper/index.qmd
figures/  → analysis/figures/
media/    → analysis/media/
data/     → analysis/data/

In analysis/paper/ (for editing):

figures/ → ../figures/
media/   → ../media/
data/    → ../data/

Why symlinks? - Quarto expects posts/*/index.qmd at root - ZZCOLLAB/rrtools puts content in analysis/paper/ - Symlinks bridge both conventions - Image paths like ![](media/images/hero.jpg) work automatically

3.4 Step 4: Verify Structure

# Check root symlinks
ls -la | grep "^l"

# Should show all 4 symlinks ✓
# index.qmd → analysis/paper/index.qmd
# figures → analysis/figures
# media → analysis/media
# data → analysis/data

# Check paper directory
ls -la analysis/paper/

# Should show:
# figures → ../figures
# media → ../media
# data → ../data
# index.qmd (actual file)

4 Part 3: Convert Markdown to Quarto Blog Post

4.1 Create Proper YAML Frontmatter

Replace the template YAML with your blog post metadata:

---
title: "Your Blog Post Title"
subtitle: "Optional subtitle (2-3 words)"
author: "Your Name"
date: "2025-12-02"
categories: [Category1, Category2, Category3]
description: "2-3 sentence summary of the post"
image: "media/images/hero-image.jpg"
document-type: "blog"
draft: false
execute:
  echo: true
  warning: false
  message: false
format:
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-depth: 3
    code-fold: false
    code-tools: false
---

Key fields: - title: 50-70 characters, searchable, descriptive - categories: 2-4 relevant categories for filtering - description: Appears in blog listing, capture value proposition - draft: false: Set to true to hide from publication - date: Publish date (or last-modified for auto-update) - code-fold: false: Show code by default (good for tutorials)

4.2 Structure Your Content

Blog post structure (proven effective):

1. Hero image + subtitle (1 paragraph)
2. Introduction (2-3 paragraphs)
   - What this post covers
   - Why it matters
   - What they'll learn
3. Problem statement or background (2-3 sections)
4. Solution/main content (multiple detailed sections)
5. Code examples or implementation (complete, runnable)
6. Usage instructions (step-by-step)
7. Examples with actual output
8. Best practices (tips and recommendations)
9. Troubleshooting (common issues)
10. Key takeaways (callout box summary)
11. Further reading (links to related docs)

4.3 Adapt Your Markdown

Markdown → Quarto conversions:

# Simple heading → stays the same
## Sub-heading → stays the same

[Link text](url) → stays the same
![Alt text](path) → stays the same
- Bullet → stays the same

> Blockquote → becomes :::callout-note

Special: Convert blockquotes to Quarto callouts

::: {.callout-note}
## Summary

Your key takeaway goes here
:::

4.4 Code Blocks Matter

Make code blocks production-ready:

#!/bin/bash
# Complete, runnable example
# Comments explaining non-obvious parts
set -e  # Exit on error

# Actual working code
your_command --with-options

Best practices: - Specify language (bash, r, python, sql, etc) - Make examples self-contained - Include comments for clarity - Test them before publishing

5 Part 4: Add Media Assets

5.1 Prepare Images

# Copy your hero image
cp ~/path/to/hero-image.jpg analysis/media/images/my-post-hero.jpg

# Copy other images (concept art, diagrams, etc)
cp ~/path/to/concept-image.png analysis/media/images/my-post-concept.png

5.2 Document Image Sources

Create a README in the images directory:

cat > analysis/media/images/README.md << 'EOF'
# Image Sources and Attribution

## my-post-hero.jpg
- Source: Unsplash / Pixabay / Pexels
- Creator: [Creator Name if known]
- License: [License type]
- URL: [Link to original if available]

## my-post-concept.png
- Source: [Where it came from]
- License: [CC0, CC-BY, etc]
- Notes: [Any other relevant info]
EOF

Why document sources? - Respect creator attribution - Document licensing compliance - Make it easy to replace if needed - Good practice for professional blogs

5.3 Reference Images in Blog Post

![Descriptive alt text](media/images/my-post-hero.jpg){.img-fluid}

*Subtitle or caption for the image*

The {.img-fluid} class makes images responsive on mobile.

6 Part 5: Update Project Metadata

6.1 Customize README.md

The ZZCOLLAB template creates a generic README. Personalize it:

# Your Blog Post Title

> A blog post about [topic]

## Quick Start

To read this blog post:

```bash
quarto render analysis/paper/index.qmd
open index.html

6.2 Structure

  • analysis/paper/index.qmd - Main blog post content
  • analysis/media/images/ - Hero image and diagrams
  • Dockerfile - Reproducible environment
  • renv.lock - R package versions

6.3 To Extend This Post

Add R analysis:

Rscript analysis/scripts/01_prepare_data.R
Rscript analysis/scripts/02_generate_figures.R
quarto render analysis/paper/index.qmd

## Update DESCRIPTION File

```r
Package: myblogpost
Title: Your Blog Post Title Here
Description: Brief description of what the post covers
Version: 1.0.0
Authors@R: person("Your Name", role = c("aut", "cre"))

7 Part 6: Test and Validate

7.1 Quick Validation

# Verify symlinks are correct
ls -la index.qmd
# Should show: index.qmd -> analysis/paper/index.qmd ✓

# Check YAML syntax (proper indentation, no tabs)
head -25 analysis/paper/index.qmd

# Verify image paths are relative
grep "images/" analysis/paper/index.qmd
# Should show: media/images/filename.jpg (not absolute path)

7.2 Render Locally (If Quarto Installed)

cd ~/prj/qblog/posts/my_blog_post
quarto render analysis/paper/index.qmd

# Preview in browser
open index.html

Common issues:

Error Cause Fix
index.qmd not found Symlink broken Check: ls -la index.qmd
Image not found Wrong path Use relative: media/images/file.jpg
YAML parse error Indentation (tabs?) Use spaces only
Code not highlighted Wrong language Specify: ```bash not ```

8 Part 7: Integration with Parent Blog

Your parent Quarto blog’s _quarto.yml should already have:

project:
  type: website
  render:
    - "posts/*/index.qmd"

Great news: Because we used symlinks, Quarto automatically finds your post!

No changes needed to parent blog configuration.

When you render the parent blog:

cd ~/prj/qblog
quarto render

It discovers your post via the posts/my_blog_post/index.qmd symlink and automatically includes it in the site.

9 Part 8: Version Control

9.1 Commit Your Work

cd ~/prj/qblog/posts/my_blog_post

# Stage all changes
git add .

# Check what you're committing
git status

# Commit with descriptive message
git commit -m "Add blog post: Your Post Title

- analysis/paper/index.qmd: Main content
- analysis/media/images/: Hero and supporting images
- README.md: Post documentation
- Docker/renv: Reproducible environment

Topics covered:
- [Main topic 1]
- [Main topic 2]
- [Main topic 3]"

9.2 Push to Remote

git push origin main

Git handles symlinks automatically - they’re stored as text files containing the target path. When someone clones your blog, symlinks are recreated correctly.

10 Part 9: Complete Workflow Summary

10.1 Timeline and Checklist

Phase Time Task
Assessment 5 min Read markdown, plan structure
Initialize 3 min Create directory, run zzcollab
Setup 1 min Run setup_symlinks.sh
Convert 10 min Adapt markdown → Quarto
Media 5 min Add images, document sources
Metadata 3 min Update README, DESCRIPTION
Test 5 min Verify structure, validate
Commit 2 min Git add/commit/push
Total ~40 min Blog post ready

10.2 Pre-Publication Checklist

Content: - [ ] Blog post written (analysis/paper/index.qmd) - [ ] All sections complete - [ ] Code examples tested - [ ] Links verified (no 404s) - [ ] Grammar/spelling checked

Metadata: - [ ] YAML frontmatter correct - [ ] Title descriptive (50-70 chars) - [ ] Categories relevant - [ ] Description captures value - [ ] draft: false (to publish)

Media: - [ ] Hero image added - [ ] Images documented in README.md - [ ] All image paths relative (media/images/...) - [ ] Image alt text present - [ ] File sizes reasonable (< 500KB each)

Structure: - [ ] Symlinks verified (4 at root) - [ ] README.md customized - [ ] DESCRIPTION updated - [ ] .gitignore appropriate

Testing: - [ ] Local render successful (if Quarto installed) - [ ] All images display - [ ] All links work - [ ] Code syntax highlighted - [ ] TOC generates correctly

11 Part 10: Extending Your Blog Post

Once published, you can enhance your post:

11.1 Add R Analysis

Create analysis scripts:

# analysis/scripts/01_prepare_data.R
library(tidyverse)
# ... your analysis code ...
write_csv(results, "analysis/data/derived_data/results.csv")

Update Makefile:

post-analysis:
    Rscript analysis/scripts/01_prepare_data.R
    Rscript analysis/scripts/02_generate_figures.R

post-render: post-analysis
    quarto render index.qmd

11.2 Add Interactive Content

Quarto supports multiple languages:

// Observable JS for interactive visualizations
Plot.plot({
  // ... your D3/Observable code ...
})
# R code with Shiny for interactive elements
library(shiny)
library(plotly)

11.3 Version Updates

When you update the post:

# Edit content
vim analysis/paper/index.qmd

# Update date (if using last-modified)
# Or change manually: date: "2025-12-15"

# Render and test
quarto render analysis/paper/index.qmd

# Commit update
git add .
git commit -m "Update post: [what changed]"
git push

12 Part 11: Troubleshooting Guide

12.1 Symlink Issues

Symlink appears broken after cloning:

# Git may not have recreated symlinks correctly
# Recreate manually:
cd ~/prj/qblog/posts/my_blog_post
rm index.qmd media figures data
ln -s analysis/paper/index.qmd index.qmd
ln -s analysis/media media
ln -s analysis/figures figures
ln -s analysis/data data

12.2 YAML Errors

“YAML parsing error”:

# Check for tabs (they're not allowed)
cat -A analysis/paper/index.qmd | head -30
# Tabs show as ^I, spaces don't

# Fix by using your editor in spaces-only mode
vim analysis/paper/index.qmd
:set expandtab

12.3 Quarto Issues

“Quarto executable not found”:

# Install Quarto
# macOS:
brew install quarto

# Or download from: https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/

Code blocks not syntax-highlighted:

# Wrong:
```shell
code

13 Right:

code

Quarto recognizes: bash, sh, r, python, sql, javascript, html, css, java, etc.

# Part 12: Best Practices

## Writing for Web Readers

- **Skim-friendly**: Use lots of headings and short paragraphs
- **Scannable**: Bullet points over long paragraphs
- **Linked**: Include links to related docs/resources
- **Examples**: Show actual output, not just descriptions
- **Progressive**: Start simple, build complexity

## Metadata Strategy

**Title**:
- Include searchable keywords
- Be specific (avoid "A Guide To Everything")
- Keep under 70 characters

**Categories**:
- Consistent across your blog
- 2-4 per post
- Enables filtering

**Description**:
- 2-3 sentences maximum
- Appears in blog listing
- Lead with value proposition

## Code Example Quality

**Test code before publishing**:
```bash
# Run the example yourself
bash example-script.sh

# Verify output matches what you document
# Fix any issues before publishing

Complete examples: - Include necessary imports - Show all required setup - Provide full, working code - Don’t make readers guess

14 Part 13: Real-World Example

This blog post itself is a working example! Let me show you:

14.1 Structure Used Here

markdown_to_blog/
├── index.qmd (symlink) → analysis/paper/index.qmd
├── media/ (symlink) → analysis/media/
├── analysis/
│   ├── paper/
│   │   └── index.qmd (THIS FILE, ~3000 words)
│   └── media/
│       └── images/
│           ├── README.md (document image sources)
│           └── [hero and concept images]

14.2 What Was Converted

Source: markdown_to_blogpost.md (process documentation, ~1300 lines)

Converted to: This blog post (teaching audience how to do it)

14.3 Key Decisions Made

Decision Outcome
Slug markdown_to_blog (kebab-case)
Profile ubuntu_standard_publishing
Content Educational (teaching, not documenting)
Structure Progressive (overview → details → checklist)
Examples Reference actual GitHub archive post

15 Key Takeaways

NoteSummary: From Markdown to Published Blog Post
  1. Dual-symlink system solves the ZZCOLLAB + Quarto compatibility puzzle
  2. ZZCOLLAB initialization gives you reproducibility from the start
  3. Minimal conversion effort - mostly structural (YAML, headings)
  4. 40 minutes total - from markdown to committed, ready to publish
  5. No parent blog changes - symlinks make integration seamless
  6. Extensible foundation - can add analysis, media, interactivity later

The workflow is repeatable: Once you’ve done it once, converting additional posts becomes faster and more automatic.

Most importantly: Your valuable documentation gets discovered, reaches your audience, and contributes to your blog’s growth.
